author: Jim Newton
title: Officials declare progress in fight against bullying Lake County News-Sun
text:
A plague that stalks school hallways, playgrounds, buses and social media, traumatizing victims at intensely vulnerable ages, is "on the decline" due to a series of targeted efforts, local officials said.
Lake County schools, social agencies and law enforcement are declaring progress against bullying.
Stepped up informational efforts, anonymous tip lines at schools and the shock of national cases involving teens who have killed themselves in the face of cyber bullying all have resulted in intensified local cooperation and programs to address the issue, local officials said in recent interviews.
The county's largest school district and the 10th largest in the state, Waukegan Unit School District 60, has seen a significant reduction in bullying incidents over the past few years, according to school officials.
Kaneland sets up online tip form to report bullying Linda Girardi Kaneland School District 302 has set up an anonymous online tip form for students and parents to report bullying.
The form can also be used to anonymously report other disruptive behavior as well.

(Linda Girardi) Dr. William Newby, an associate superintendent at District 60, said incidents officially classified as bullying have declined over the past four years, from 44 during the 2011-2012 school year to 28 during the 2013-2014 school year. The figures are collected and reported every two years under state statute and federal guidelines.
In the fall of 2012, District 60 unveiled the Rise Above anti-bullying a program, which was developed in conjunction with the Lake County State's Attorney's office and subsequently adopted by other districts as well.
"Our bullying curriculum is taught in P.E. classes. For us, bullying is on the decline after the program was implemented," Newby said.
Bullying cases are categorized as a pattern of behavior that continues over a period of time and impacts a student's inclination or ability to come to school, Newby said, as opposed to one-time confrontations or fights.
Under the District 60 School Board's policy on bullying, the act includes, but is not limited to, conduct such as harassment, threats, intimidation, stalking, public humiliation and physical violence.
One of the most effective anti-bullying tools, Newby said, is the anonymous tip line for students. Both school and law enforcement officials reported that anonymous options have provided a breakthrough in getting students involved in helping others who are being bullied without becoming targets themselves.
District 68 sets up tip line to report problems in schools Mike Isaacs Skokie School District 68 has added a new Safety Tip Line to its website in an effort to stop bullying and other at-risk behaviors in its schools, the district announced this week.

(Mike Isaacs) When the district receives a tip that bullying is taking place in a certain hall location or on a specific bus, teachers or staff are assigned to monitor the location, Newby said. The effort has cut into the ability of bullies to operate on district property, Newby said.
Some students have also become more willing to speak out publicly against bullying when it occurs, he said.
Many Waukegan schools pass out "I Pledge to Rise Above" wristbands, which in addition to getting students to reflect on their own behavior, sends a public notice to bullies when worn by other students.
The variety of acts that can constitute bullying, however, continues to make tracking actual incidents difficult, according to Carrie Flanigan, special programs manager in the state's attorney's office.
Flanigan said that is primarily because juvenile charges such as battery, which can constitute bullying when repeated, can also be the result of singular incidents not tied to bullying.
Flanigan and Claudia Kasten, chief of the juvenile trial division for the state's attorney's office, both noted that there are currently no countywide statistics on bullying available due to the difficulty in tracking charges such as juvenile battery that may or may not be the result of bullying.
"What we see is the bullying that gets elevated to criminal charges. But we do believe the preventative efforts are making a noticeable difference," Kasten said, adding that several agencies and offices, including the Regional Superintendent of Schools Office, are working together to promote more inclusive discussions on the issue. "One of the important things is that we are able to talk about it in the community, not just to school officials and students, but to parents and the community (to stress the importance of) modeling good behavior."

(Debbie Bosak) While Kasten said there have been no suicides in Lake County attributed to cyber bullying, she and Flanigan stressed the harm social media can cause when used to bully others.
In addition to established, popular apps such as Facebook, Twitter and Snapchat, which are sometimes abused for cyber bullying, some apps almost seem created to make things easier for bullies.
One popular app allows users to send anonymous messages to anyone signed on to the same application within a certain distance, which can allow a bully or bullies to target a student within an entire school or district.
"A lot of kids leave school crying," Flanigan said. "There are so many more of those apps these days."
But Flanigan and Kasten, who make presentations to students, faculty and sometimes parents at local schools on request, stress to students that none of the apps are as anonymous as youths and some adults think they are.
"You think (the posts) are disappearing, but they're not," Flanigan said. "We do let people know we are there."
To illustrate the point, Flanigan pulled out her cellphone, called up an app and was instantly able to point out mean-spirited messages.
"Think before you put something up," Flanigan said she tells students. "You might think it's gone, but it's not."
On a positive note, Flanigan said, funding is available to provide agencies with information and materials to help combat cyber bullying
Officials stressed, however, that while enforcement against bullying is important, to really address the problem, the offender must be reached as well as the target.

Tasha London, director of crisis intervention and safety for District 60, said motivations for bullying can vary by age group.
"Sometimes it's jealousy," London said, adding that for elementary school students, bullying can be a sign that the offender doesn't feel part of a group or that he or she has many friends.
For older children, both the seriousness of the bullying and the seriousness of its causes may increase, with factors such as domestic violence sometimes coming into play.
"There is a correlation between violent behavior in the home and increased bullying," Kasten said.

"Responsibility and accountability are important. But we have to understand that if we don't know what's causing the offender to act out, we will not be successful in stopping the behavior."
The widespread acceptance of programs such as Rise Above, the involvement of groups such as the Lake County Juvenile Justice Council, which helps provide resources and guidelines for dealing with bullying, and the establishment of tools such as anonymous tip lines are being credited with reining in bullying in Lake County.
"I definitely think the programs are having an effect," Flanigan said. "Each school is required to have a program and that in itself is big. The more we are able to talk about it, and bring it to the forefront, the better off these kids will be."

Unity Day
On Wednesday, nations around the world are observing Unity Day, an event developed by PACER's National Bullying Prevention Center to show support for preventing bullying in schools, neighborhoods and online.
Hundreds of Unity Day events are planned in the United States, and the effort is now recognized around the world with students and organizations participating in activities.
Organizers have encouraged supporters to wear orange Wednesday in recognition of the bullying problem and efforts to combat it.
Unity Day began in 2011 as part of National Bullying Prevention Month, which was launched by PACER in 2006.
PACER has created a Unity Day Facebook event that people can "attend" and share, as well as a cover photo that individuals can post on their personal Facebook pages. Unity Day updates, photos and videos can be shared on Twitter and Facebook using the hashtag #UnityDay2015.
To learn more about PACER and ways to help fight bullying, visit the organization's websites, which offer an array of information and tools. The sites are located at PACER.org/bullying, PACERKidsAgainstBullying.org, and PACERTeensAgainstBullying.org.
